summary: The U.S. District Court for the Western District of Missouri today entered a final judgment in favor of a disabled individual who was found ineligible for unemployment benefits because he was unable to work.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in St. Louis, Missouri, on April 5, 2016, a jury found that Mathew Brunk was not available to work because he had suffered a traumatic brain injury and was not able to perform any work. The SEC also found that Claimant had a specific recall date and had to pay a 25% penalty for not being able to work during the recall period.  The SEC alleges that, contrary to the Commission's findings, Claimant was not eligible to receive benefits because of his inability to work, and that he was not capable of performing the work that he had performed before his accident.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York today announced criminal charges against Claimant.  On May 24, 2016 the U. S. Attorney's office for the Eastern District of Illinois announced criminal criminal charges.  As part of the criminal charges, the SEC obtained a temporary restraining order, an asset freeze, and an officer-and-director bar against Brunk.  Without admitting or denying the allegations of the complaint, Brunk consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins him from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and orders him to pay disgorgement of $1,053, which is equal to the amount of his ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest, and a $25,000 civil penalty.  Brunk also agreed to be permanently enjoined from participating in the issuance, purchase, offer, or sale of any security deposit, and to be barred from serving as an officer or director of a public company for five years.   The settlement is subject to court approval.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 17-cv-8221 (January 3, 2016).  The Commission's complaint charges Brunk with violations of Section 288.040.1(2) and Rule 206(4)-8221(3) and seeks a permanent injunction against future violations of the federal securities laws, as well as a penalty from the Department of Justice for further determination by the Division of Employment Security (Division of Economic and Risk Analysis).  In its complaint, the Commission also alleges that Brunk violated Section 5 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and Section 15(a)(1) of
